title: A number theory problem by A Former Brilliant Member

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We only need clues (1) and (4):"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Say the numbers are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a,a+d,a+2d,a+3d,a+4d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Clue (1): "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2a+d=a+4d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=3d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and we can rewrite the list as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3d,4d,5d,6d,7d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Clues (2) and (3) follow directly from this; they're the relations "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^2+4^2=5^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^3+4^3+5^3=6^3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" respectively."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Clue (4): "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"25d=25d^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"; since the integers are positive, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and the sum is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{25}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I just solved it by just using the fourth clue in my solution üòâ

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Even if you don't use the first clue, you'll get the answer. It was added to increase the number of terms of the series. Using the second and the fourth clue or the third and the fourth clue  you can get it. :)

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Logical (and lucky) approach:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let's say we have an arithmetic sequence: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{1}, a_{2},a_{3},a_{4},a_{5}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The second clue implies that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}=a_{3}^{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", means that the first three numbers form a Pythagoras triple. When I search for the satisfied one, the trio "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(3,4,5)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" do form a arithmetic sequence (1). To check again, let's see the first clue, states that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{1}+a_{2}=a_{5}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Series (1) has common difference of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{5}=7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which satisfy the condition."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the sequence is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{3,4,5,6,7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Sum=\boxed{25}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_1+4d=a_2+3d=a_3+2d=a_4+d=a_5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_1+a_2=a_5\implies a_1=3d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_1 ^2+a_2 ^2=a_3 ^2\\
9d^2+16d^2=25d^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" - This is true for any "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_1 ^3+a_2 ^3+a_3 ^3=a_4 ^3\\
27d^3+64d^3+125d^3=216d^3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" - This is true for any "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(3+4+5+6+7)d=25d^2\implies d=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The solution is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3+4+5+6+7=\boxed{25}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Suppose the terms are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a-2d, a-d, a, a+d, a+2d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". We can get the answer just by  the 4th clue."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, as per the 4th clue,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a-2d + a-d + a + a+d+a+2d={ a }^{ 2 }"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5a={ a }^{ 2 }"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, dividing both sides by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" as it is not 0 as all are positive integers."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5=a"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus, the sum of all the terms would be "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= a-2d + a-d + a + a+d+a+2d"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=5a"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=5 \times 5 \quad .... \quad (\text{As we found} \quad a=5)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus, the sum is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5 \times 5=25"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: abc123
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/solvable/24ed7dedd8.61df695990.hhxcQH.png?width=250"}},{"type":"text","text":"\nb=135. Find (a)(c)-(a+c).\n(Suppose a is longer than b.)"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(134 + x) Sqrt [135^2 + (135+ x)^2] - (135 + x) for x = 8970 to 9530 tells that only 83019431 can match as an answer, integer some more compared to other three. Therefore, the objective question only gives one possible matching for integer of side a, although not specified, it would be preferred! "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = 8977"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a = 9112"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b= 135"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c = 9113"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1+3+5+‚Ä¶+991 + 3  + 5 + \ldots + 991+3+5+‚Ä¶+99
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is sum of  all positive odd numbers from 1 to 100?"}]}]}

title: 135th Problem 2016
An algebra problem by A Former Brilliant Member

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\text{Chance(Positivity) }=x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and so the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\text{Chance(Negativity) }=100-x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (assuming that the number isn't 0)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We have the equation:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100-x=x+\dfrac{100-x}{x}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Multiplying, and simplifying, we get:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2x^2-101x+100 = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Solving,
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = \dfrac{101 \pm \sqrt{101^2 - 4\cdot 2\cdot 100}}{4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Putting in our equation, we see that"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = \dfrac{101 + \sqrt{101^2 - 4\cdot 2\cdot 100}}{4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" satisfies the condition, so it is the answer.
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = \dfrac{101 + \sqrt{101^2 - 4\cdot 2\cdot 100}}{4} \approx 49.48"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                            Thank you for pointing it out! I was also wondering why I had cancelled that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"!

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            You did a mistake in solving the quadratic equation. It should be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in the denominator. Check your final answer also. It is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\approx 49.489688"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Solution 1:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4^{x+1}=8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^{2(x+1)}=2^3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2(x+1)=3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+1=\dfrac{3}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=\dfrac{3}{2}-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=\dfrac{3}{2}-\dfrac{2}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=\dfrac{1}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=0.5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large\color{#D61F06}\boxed{answer}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Solution 2:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"taking the natural logarithm of both sides"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4^{x+1}=8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\ln~4^{x+1}=\ln~8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x+1)\ln~4=\ln~8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+1=\dfrac{\ln~8}{\ln~2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By the use of a calculator, we get"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+1=1.5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Finally,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=0.5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large\color{#D61F06}\boxed{answer}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 13 and 117

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            To answer your second question, Brian gave an example. 13 and 119: e^(13/e) is > 119, but 2.6^5 < 119.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I had the same approach in terms of estimation. It's interesting that there have to be exactly "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" numbers - both "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left(\frac{13}{4}\right)^4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left(\frac{13}{6}\right)^6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are too small. Are there any other sets of rationals that work? Are there infinitely many? Are there examples of similar questions where this estimation technique doesn't work? (ie we're looking for a set of rationals with sum "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", product "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P<e^{S/e}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", but none exists).

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Nice question. I first checked to see what the maximum product of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such rational numbers which added to 13 could possibly be. This is achieved when all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" numbers are the same value "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a = \dfrac{13}{n}, n \lt 13"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". For a non-integral value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" the maximum of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^{n} = \left(\dfrac{13}{n}\right)^{n}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e^{13/e} \approx 119.4 \gt 117"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which prompted me to go ahead and guess 'Yes', but I wasn't able to prove to myself that this could be achieved with rational numbers only, as your example does. (Note that for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a = 13/5 = 2.6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", roughly in line with your example, we get  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^{5} \approx 118.8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which suggests that any solution set would have to involve 5 rational numbers) I'll have to give this more thought. Anyway, a follow-up question would be the same but with 120 (or even 119) replacing 117, the answer to which would definitely be 'No'.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Partly answering my own question: the set "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2. \dot{2},2.6,2.7,2.7,2.\dot{7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" also works.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 13, 7 and whatnot.
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A number ‚Äòn‚Äô when multiplied with 13 has only digit 7‚Äôs in the product (i.e., 777 ...7). Let the product be denoted by m."}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the sum of distinct digits in the smallest such n."}]}]}

title: 1/3 is a nice number for this case

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"O,G,H"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are the outcentre, centroid and orthocentre of the triangle, then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"OH = 3OG"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and so the required condition is the same as asking that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"OH < 3r"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", or that the orthocentre lies inside the outcircle of the triangle."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now the orthocentre of a triangle lies on the outcircle precisely when the triangle is right-angled, and lies outside the outcircle when the triangle is obtuse-angled. Thus we are asking for the probability that the triangle is acute-angled."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Without loss of generality, one point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" on the triangle can be assumed to be fixed. The second point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" will form an angle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\theta = \angle AOB"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0 \le \theta \le \pi"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\theta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is uniformly distributed over "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[0,\pi]"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The triangle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ABC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" will be acute-angled precisely when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" lies on the arc of the circumcircle which is diametrically opposite the minor arc "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AB"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". This is an arc subtending the same angle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\theta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" at the centre of the circle. Thus the probability that the triangle is acute-angled is
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{1}{\pi} \int_0^\pi \frac{\theta}{2\pi}\,d\theta \; = \; \frac14 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
making the answer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{0.25}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            That makes sense, more triangles can have  a centroid towards the center of L. Thanks!

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Any point inside "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"L"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" could be the centroid, but different points are not equally likely. You are assuming the the location of the centroid is uniformly distributed over the circle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"L"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is not the case.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I don't agree with 1/4. If each point is equally likely to be chosen, then any point within circle L can be the centroid of triangle ABC. Going along with this, then we only need to find the ratio of the two circles' areas, which isn't 1/4. A ratio of two areas, l/L, would give 1/9. Granted, this would be the limit of that probability because you can only get the centroid of triangle ABC so close to the edge of circle L. If my logic is incorrect someone enlighten me.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Why do you multiply the integral by 1/pi?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Here's a no-calculus proof. Each point divides the big circle into two semicircles (using the diameter through that point). To be in the arc diametrically opposite to the minor arc "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AB"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has to lie in the semicircle defined by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that does not contain "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (this happens with probability "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\tfrac12"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":") and also in the semicircle defined by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that does not contain "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (this happens with probability "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\tfrac12"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"). It turns out that being in the opposite "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"-semicircle to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and being in the opposite "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"-semicircle to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are independent events, and hence the probability that both events happen is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\tfrac12 \times \tfrac12 = \tfrac14"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Yes, the centroid will lie in the small circle if the midpoint of the other two vertices lies in a circle of area "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\big(\tfrac32\big)^2\pi = \tfrac94\pi"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", whose area is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\tfrac14"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of that of the big circle."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What you seem to be assuming is that the midpoint of the other two sides is uniformly distributed over the big circle. It is not.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Great solution! The only thing I can't understand is this: "Given any point inside the circle, there is a unique set of 2 other points such that the two other points' midpoint is the given point.". While it makes some sense intuitively, is there a way to prove it?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A graphical simulation of the problem.
"},{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/Qh1yMFEgzf-centroid_locus.png?width=1200"}},{"type":"text","text":"
For a fixed point A, generate the locus of the centroid for different positions of the other two vertices of the triangle.
The centroid is located within a circle of radius two, which contains the target circle of radius one.
Ratio of these areas is therefore 4:1, giving a probability of 0.25."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            You are assuming that the location of the centroid is uniformly distributed over its locus. This is not true.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

replies.body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Calvin Lin ‚Äì "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Assume that the point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is fixed, and that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are uniformly and independently distributed over the circle. Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AD"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be a diameter, and let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the midpoint of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"OD"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/xprT3BCQKi-image1.jpg?width=250"}}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The polar coordinates of the midpoint "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"M"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"BC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(s,\alpha)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"s = 3\cos\tfrac12\theta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\theta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the non-reflex angle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle BOC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\theta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are essentially the difference and average of the two polar angles of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the random variables "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\theta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are independent. Note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\theta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is uniformly distributed over "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(0,\pi)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", while "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is uniformly distributed over "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(-\pi,\pi)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \mathbb{P}[s \le u] \; =\; \mathbb{P}[\cos\tfrac12\theta \le \tfrac13u] \; = \; 1 - \tfrac{2}{\pi}\cos^{-1}\tfrac13u \hspace{2cm} 0 \le u \le 3 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" and hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"s"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has the probability distribution function "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" f_s(u) \; = \; \frac{2}{\pi\sqrt{9-u^2}} \hspace{2cm} 0 \le u \le 3 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" Note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"s"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are independent. The centroid "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"G"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of the triangle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ABC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is obtained by enlarging "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"M"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" by a factor of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\tfrac23"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" through the point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Suppose that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the distance "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"OG"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of the centroid from the centre of the circle. Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r \le u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" precisely when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"G"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" lies in the circle, centre "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"O"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of radius "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and this occurs precisely when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"M"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" lies in the circle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mathcal{C}_u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of centre "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and radius "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\tfrac32u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus the probability that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r \le u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the probability that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"M"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" lies in the intersection of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mathcal{C}_u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and the original circle."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/uV7Yqc8lgc-image2.jpg?width=200"}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/gKrGUAZoZh-image3.jpg?width=200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"When "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0 < u < 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" the circle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mathcal{C}_u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" lies entirely inside the original circle, and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mathcal{C}_u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can be described in polar coordinates as follows: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \tfrac32(1-u) \;\le \; s \; \le \; \tfrac32(1+u) \hspace{2cm} |\alpha| \;\le \; \cos^{-1}\left(\frac{4s^2 + 9 - 9u^2}{12s}\right) "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" Thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} \mathbb{P}[r \le u] & = \tfrac{2}{\pi^2}\int_{\frac32(1-u)}^{\frac32(1+u)} \cos^{-1}\left(\frac{4s^2 + 9 - 9u^2}{12s}\right)\, \frac{ds}{\sqrt{9-s^2}} \\ & = \tfrac{2}{\pi^2} \int_{1-u}^{1+u} \cos^{-1}\left(\frac{v^2 + 1 - u^2}{2v}\right)\,\frac{dv}{\sqrt{4-v^2}} \hspace{2cm} 0 < u < 1 \end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"When "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 < u < 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" the situation is more complicated, since the circle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mathcal{C}_u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" contains "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"O"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and extends beyond the original circle. For us to have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r \le u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we must have either "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"s < \tfrac32(u-1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or else "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\tfrac32(u-1) < s < 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"|\alpha| \le \cos^{-1}\left(\frac{4s^2 + 9 - 9u^2}{12s}\right)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} \mathbb{P}[r \le u] & = \tfrac{2}{\pi}\int_0^{\frac32(u-1)}\frac{dv}{\sqrt{9-v^2}} + \tfrac{2}{\pi^2}\int_{\frac32(u-1)}^3 \cos^{-1}\left(\frac{4s^2 + 9 - 9u^2}{12s}\right)\,\frac{ds}{\sqrt{9-s^2}} \\ & = \tfrac{2}{\pi}\sin^{-1}\frac{u-1}{2} + \tfrac{2}{\pi^2}\int_{u-1}^2 \cos^{-1}\left(\frac{v^2 + 1 - u^2}{2v}\right)\,\frac{dv}{\sqrt{4-v^2}} \hspace{2cm} 1 < u < 3 \end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" Thus we have a piecewise definition for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F_r(u) = \mathbb{P}[r \le u]"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which does not seem likely to be something we can evaluate exactly! Here is a numerical plot of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F_r"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/6GQjikbmr8-image4.jpg?width=400"}}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F(1) = \tfrac14"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", as expected. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Calvin Lin ‚Äì "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" I can obtain an expression for the CDF "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(r)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", at least for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            In that same train of thought, if we let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" f(r) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the cdf for the probability that the point lies in the circle of radius "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then we know that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" f(0) = 0 , f(2) = 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". We would love to claim that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" f(r) = \frac{ r^2 } { 4 } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" by a geometric argument, but in order to do so, we have to consider where these "centroid points" lie."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For a visual simulation of this difference, model the location of 100 (or 1000) of these centroid points. You will notice that they tend to be clustered around the center, as opposed to around the sides. As such, the density of these centroid points is "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Follow up question: Can we determine "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" f(r) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"? "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note: The red points are too regular (they form many circles!), which suggests to me that you are taking fixed variations of B and C, as opposed to truly random ones. Even then, the difference becomes "apparent from the density of red at the center of the red area."

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            It's intriguing, isn't it? Ex Money had a different take on the problem, assuming that the midpoint of two sides was uniformly distributed over the large circle, and again obtained "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\tfrac14"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for the wrong reasons. However, in both cases, the probability that a particular point lies in a region involves averaging the probability (technically, integrating the probability density function) of the point occurring everywhere in the region. It just so happens that this process of integrating probabilities gives the same answer as if you assumed that the points were distributed uniformly. This would not be the case if you changed the radius of the smaller circle.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I guess that is apparent from the density of red at the centre of the red area. But then why does this still give the correct answer??

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}
